meta.title: Anesthesia E&D - Mission NEET PG 2.0 - Final Batch - 09-06-2025 - 2025-06-09

questions.text: A 70-year-old man scheduled for laparotomy has a history of ischemic heart disease and an ejection fraction of 30%. He is on aspirin, clopidogrel, and carvedilol. His pre-op ECG shows Q waves in the inferior leads. What is the most appropriate test to assess cardiac risk before surgery?

Which of the following statements about pediatric anesthesia are true? Infants have higher minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) than adults. Succinylcholine is preferred over rocuronium for rapid sequence induction in infants. Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent for induction in children. Pediatric airways are narrowest at the cricoid ring.
Match the following clinical tests with what they assess in airway examination:
A patient on chronic lithium therapy for bipolar disorder is scheduled for elective hernia surgery under general anesthesia. What is the correct perioperative plan for lithium?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue lithium till morning of surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Switch lithium to valproate 1 week before surgery

questions.correct_answer: C. Stop lithium 48 hours before surgery
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Stop lithium 48 hours before surgery

questions.text: Which of the following are true regarding adult cardiac arrest and CPR? Pulse check should be for no more than 10 seconds. High-quality chest compressions must achieve a depth of 5–6 cm. Bag-mask ventilation with room air is acceptable in early CPR. Chest compression to ventilation ratio is 15:2 in adults.
Assertion: In pediatric CPR, both single and two-rescuer methods recommend 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio. Reason: Children are more prone to arrhythmias as the primary cause of arrest.

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R true, R explains A

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and R true, R does not explain A

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and R are false

questions.correct_answer: D. Both A and R are false
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Both A and R are false

questions.text: Which of the following best identifies this ultrasound view?
What is the most likely block being performed?
What is the most appropriate identification of the structure marked in the image and its clinical relevance?

options.label: A
options.text: Carotid artery; compressible structure best avoided for central access

options.label: B
options.text: Internal jugular vein; preferred site for central venous catheter placement

options.label: C
options.text: Subclavian vein; difficult to visualize above the clavicle

options.label: D
options.text: External jugular vein; not suitable for ultrasound-guided central line

questions.correct_answer: B. Internal jugular vein; preferred site for central venous catheter placement
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Internal jugular vein; preferred site for central venous catheter placement

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at term requests labor analgesia. She has a platelet count of 60,000/mm³ and no other abnormalities. Which analgesic technique is contraindicated?
Match the drug with its appropriate timing of discontinuation pre-op:
Assertion: Bupivacaine is avoided in intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA). Reason: Bupivacaine is cardiotoxic and has a long half-life.

options.label: A
options.text: A true, R true, R explains A

options.label: B
options.text: A true, R true, R does not explain A

questions.correct_answer: A. A true, R true, R explains A
questions.explanation: Ans. A) A true, R true, R explains A

questions.text: Which of the following are reliable predictors of difficult intubation? Mallampati Grade III or IV Interincisor gap <3 cm Thyromental distance >7 cm Limited atlanto-occipital extension
Assertion: Spinal anesthesia causes more profound hypotension than epidural in cesarean section. Reason: Spinal anesthesia produces rapid sympathetic block compared to gradual onset in epidural.

options.label: A
options.text: A true, R true, R explains A

options.label: B
options.text: A true, R true, R does not explain A

questions.correct_answer: A. A true, R true, R explains A
questions.explanation: Ans. A) A true, R true, R explains A

questions.text: Match the drug with its indication in CPR:
A 40-year-old woman undergoing C-section under spinal anesthesia suddenly complains of breathlessness and upper chest tightness. BP is 80/40 mmHg and HR is 50 bpm. What is the likely cause?
Which of the following statements is true regarding differences between the pediatric and adult airway?

options.label: A
options.text: In infants, the narrowest portion of the airway is at the level of the vocal cords, unlike adults where it's subglottic

options.label: B
options.text: The pediatric epiglottis is firm and flat, making intubation easier

options.label: C
options.text: The pediatric larynx is positioned at a lower cervical level compared to adults

options.label: D
options.text: The pediatric airway has a funnel-shaped larynx and a narrowest point at the subglottic region

questions.correct_answer: D. The pediatric airway has a funnel-shaped larynx and a narrowest point at the subglottic region
questions.explanation: Ans. D) The pediatric airway has a funnel-shaped larynx and a narrowest point at the subglottic region

questions.text: Assertion (A): Propofol is the induction agent of choice in day-care surgeries. Reason (R): Propofol causes prolonged sedation but low incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting hence preferred.

options.label: A
options.text: A is true, R is true, and R explains A

options.label: B
options.text: A is true, R is true, but R does not explain A

options.label: C
options.text: A is true, R is false

options.label: D
options.text: A is false, R is true

questions.correct_answer: C. A is true, R is false
questions.explanation: Ans. C) A is true, R is false

questions.text: What is the name of the maneuver being demonstrated in the given image?
A 68-year-old man with EF 30% undergoing hernia repair under general anesthesia receives IV propofol for induction and develops hypotension (70/40 mmHg). What is the most likely mechanism?

A 65-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension is scheduled for surgery. According to the American Society of Anesthesiologists' Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification, what is his classification?

The anesthetist applies a cream with an occlusive dressing on the hand of a 1 year old baby brought for IV cannulation so that he does not feel pain of cannulation. What is the composition of the cream that was applied?
Which of these values are monitored using capnography?
questions.correct_answer: D. Amount of expired carbon dioxide
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Amount of expired carbon dioxide

questions.text: Assertion (A): Preloading with IV fluids prevents hypotension after spinal anesthesia. Reason (R): Fluid bolus increases sympathetic tone and causes vasoconstriction.

options.label: A
options.text: A is true, R is true, and R explains A

options.label: B
options.text: A is true, R is true, but R does not explain A

options.label: C
options.text: A is true, R is false

options.label: D
options.text: A is false, R is true

questions.correct_answer: C. A is true, R is false
questions.explanation: Ans. C) A is true, R is false

questions.text: What is the most likely first clinical sign of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)?
A 29-year-old woman with ITP (platelet count 38,000/mm³) is scheduled for elective C-section. What is the most appropriate anesthetic technique?
A 42-year-old female is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. What is the airway device most likely being used?

A 65-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, hypertension, and mild chronic renal impairment is scheduled for elective hernia repair surgery. His preoperative assessment shows normal liver function, but he has a history of moderate asthma, for which he uses an inhaler intermittently. He is obese with a BMI of 35. The anesthesiologist is considering the best inhalational agent for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, taking into account the patient's comorbidities and the nature of the surgery. Which inhalational agent is most appropriate for this patient?

A 45-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with acute dehydration secondary to gastroenteritis. The patient is hemodynamically stable but requires intravenous (IV) fluid resuscitation. The attending physician orders an IV cannula for fluid administration, and the nurse is considering the appropriate gauge of the cannula to be used based on the required flow rate for adequate resuscitation. Which of the following IV cannula sizes would be most appropriate for this patient’s fluid resuscitation?

A 55-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) is scheduled for elective coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery. The patient has been on dual antiplatelet therapy for the past 6 months, which includes Abciximab and Eptifibatide. His surgeon is concerned about the increased risk of bleeding during surgery due to the prolonged effect of these drugs and seeks advice on when to discontinue these medications preoperatively. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for discontinuing these anticoagulants before surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Abciximab should be stopped 48 hours before surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Eptifibatide should be stopped 24 hours before surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Herbal medicines should be stopped 1-2 days before surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Abciximab should be stopped 12 hours before surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Abciximab should be stopped 48 hours before surgery
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Abciximab should be stopped 48 hours before surgery

questions.text: A 23-year-old male with no prior anesthetic exposure undergoes posterior spinal fusion under general anesthesia. Midway through the case, the anesthesiologist notices increasing end-tidal CO₂ (rising from 35 to 70 mmHg over 15 minutes), sinus tachycardia (HR 145 bpm), and general muscle rigidity. Core temperature is currently 37.6°C. Arterial blood gas reveals pH 7.21, PaCO₂ 65 mmHg, and elevated serum potassium. Which of the following findings, if present, would most strongly support a diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia over other causes of hypercarbia?

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased minute ventilation despite increasing tidal volumes

options.label: C
options.text: Use of halothane as the volatile anesthetic

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory acidosis without associated lactic acidosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Masseter spasm following succinylcholine administration
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Masseter spasm following succinylcholine administration

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with Alzheimer’s disease is undergoing short orthopedic surgery. She has been on donepezil and quetiapine for several months. Induction is initiated with etomidate. Seconds after administration, she becomes apneic, develops generalized rigidity, and masseter muscle spasm. What is the most plausible explanation for this reaction?

options.label: C
options.text: Malignant hyperthermia precipitated by unrecognized susceptibility

options.label: D
options.text: Exaggerated central nervous system excitation by etomidate

questions.text: A 60-kg man requires multiple-site infiltration with lignocaine (lidocaine) without epinephrine for a cosmetic procedure. The surgeon plans to use 30 mL of 2% lidocaine (20 mg / ml ). Which of the following is the most accurate assessment?

options.label: A
options.text: Dose is well within safe limits

options.label: B
options.text: Dose exceeds recommended maximum and risks systemic toxicity

options.label: C
options.text: Epinephrine addition would not allow a higher volume

options.label: D
options.text: Dose is too low to produce any anesthetic effect

questions.correct_answer: B. Dose exceeds recommended maximum and risks systemic toxicity
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Dose exceeds recommended maximum and risks systemic toxicity

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of depression and chronic alcohol use is undergoing an emergency below-knee amputation. Anesthesia is induced with etomidate, and within 10 seconds he develops brief generalized tonic movements. Vitals are stable. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Abort surgery and order head CT

options.label: C
options.text: Proceed with anesthesia—no specific treatment required

options.label: D
options.text: Switch to propofol to prevent recurrence

questions.correct_answer: C. Proceed with anesthesia—no specific treatment required
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Proceed with anesthesia—no specific treatment required

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with interstitial lung disease and poor effort tolerance is scheduled for TURP. He has a history of moderate COPD and is on home oxygen. Which inhalational anesthetic agent is most appropriate if general anesthesia is needed?
A 45-year-old factory worker with a forearm fracture is planned for closed reduction under Bier's block . Before proceeding, he is noted to have Raynaud’s phenomenon . What should the anesthetist do?

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid the block and choose brachial plexus block

options.label: C
options.text: Add clonidine to prolong block duration

questions.correct_answer: B. Avoid the block and choose brachial plexus block
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Avoid the block and choose brachial plexus block

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with signs of peritonitis and shock . On examination, his BP is 80/50 mmHg , HR is 110 bpm, and he is cold and clammy. He is scheduled for emergency laparotomy under general anesthesia. Which of the following induction agents is most appropriate for this patient?

A 68-year-old male with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The treating physician decides to apply Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) to improve oxygenation. Following the adjustment, various physiological parameters are closely monitored to evaluate the effects of PEEP on the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status. What is one of the effects of applying PEEP (Positive End Expiratory Pressure) in this patient?
During a cesarean section under spinal anesthesia, a patient experiences a significant drop in blood pressure and tachycardia. Which of the following is the primary mechanism causing this?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased cardiac output due to sympathetic stimulation

options.label: B
options.text: Blockade of parasympathetic nerve fibers leading to increased heart rate

options.label: C
options.text: Blockade of sympathetic nerve fibers causing vasodilation in the lower extremities

options.label: D
options.text: Direct negative inotropic effect of the anesthetic on the myocardium

questions.correct_answer: C. Blockade of sympathetic nerve fibers causing vasodilation in the lower extremities
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Blockade of sympathetic nerve fibers causing vasodilation in the lower extremities

questions.text: Which of the following modes of ventilation is generally not used for weaning patients from mechanical ventilation?

A 50-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode at home. Her husband reports that she has been using a topical medication for chronic back pain. On examination, she is cyanotic but breathing comfortably. Pulse oximetry is low despite breathing room air. Arterial blood gas shows a normal PaO₂, and methemoglobin levels are elevated. Which of the following drugs is least likely to be associated with the development of methemoglobinemia?

A 70-year-old male with end-stage renal disease and decompensated liver cirrhosis is posted for emergency exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following neuromuscular blocking agents is most appropriate?

A 45-year-old woman undergoes laparoscopic hysterectomy under general anesthesia using rocuronium. Sugammadex is administered at the end of surgery for neuromuscular reversal. Within minutes, she develops profound bradycardia and transient hypotension. Which of the following is most likely responsible?

options.label: A
options.text: Incomplete reversal due to inadequate sugammadex dose

questions.correct_answer: C. Direct cardiovascular effect of sugammadex
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Direct cardiovascular effect of sugammadex

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoing awake craniotomy is given a continuous infusion of remifentanil for intraoperative analgesia. Despite a 6-hour infusion, he awakens rapidly within 2–3 minutes of stopping the drug. What pharmacokinetic property explains this?

options.label: A
options.text: High lipid solubility with rapid redistribution

questions.correct_answer: C. Organ-independent hydrolysis by plasma esterases
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Organ-independent hydrolysis by plasma esterases

questions.text: A 32-year-old man undergoing posterior fossa tumor resection in the sitting position suddenly develops a drop in end-tidal CO₂ from 34 mmHg to 20 mmHg, accompanied by hypotension and mill wheel murmur on precordial auscultation. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate administration of 100% oxygen and flood surgical field

options.label: D
options.text: Switch from general to spinal anesthesia

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate administration of 100% oxygen and flood surgical field
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Immediate administration of 100% oxygen and flood surgical field

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is undergoing a lengthy laparoscopic pelvic surgery as shown below. Two hours into the procedure, she develops facial edema and increased airway pressure. Which of the following is the most likely complication?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intracranial pressure and airway edema

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased intracranial pressure and airway edema
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Increased intracranial pressure and airway edema

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a strong family history of malignant hyperthermia is scheduled for elective thyroidectomy. Which of the following anesthetic strategies is most appropriate for her?

options.label: A
options.text: Isoflurane with nitrous oxide and fentanyl infusion

options.label: B
options.text: Sevoflurane induction followed by propofol infusion

options.label: C
options.text: Total intravenous anesthesia using propofol and remifentanil

options.label: D
options.text: Spinal anesthesia with bupivacaine and midazolam sedation

questions.correct_answer: C. Total intravenous anesthesia using propofol and remifentanil
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Total intravenous anesthesia using propofol and remifentanil

questions.text: A 54-year-old chronic smoker with a 35-pack-year history is scheduled for elective hernia repair under general anesthesia. He denies recent respiratory infection but has chronic cough with expectoration. Which of the following is a recognized complication of administering general anesthesia to this patient?

A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with signs of peritonitis and intestinal perforation. He is scheduled for an emergency laparotomy. The abdominal X-ray is as given below. Which of the following anesthetic agents should be avoided in this patient?

A 28-year-old man with polytrauma is rushed to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He is unconscious and has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 6. Intubation is planned for airway protection. The team considers administering succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation. His chart shows that he had a spinal cord injury 2 weeks ago and is now paraplegic. Which of the following is the most serious risk of administering succinylcholine in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Prolonged neuromuscular blockade due to pseudocholinesterase deficiency
